issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

fields.summary: AWS does not allow a security group to be deleted if another security group's rule depends on it

status.description: This issue has been validated/reproduced, but has not been prioritized yet.
status.name: Confirmed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
If a security group contains a rule that allows traffic from another security group, which is later deleted, then the attempt to edit the group's rule would result in error.

The bigger issue is that once the error occurs, the security group would lose all the rules since in the server, 'delete' rules come before 'add' rules.
fields.summary: If security group rule contains a deleted security group for allowing traffic, the attempt to edit the rules would result in error

comments.body:
[~jloza] Implemented a check to make sure that the security groups in the rules exist before adding them to rules, and if not, skip the rules from created. However, currently there is no mechanism in place to warn user if this action occurs.
 
For instance, let's say a security group X contains the rules below.

TCP (443) 0.0.0.0/0
TCP (22) 521426283155/ VPC group with other SGs allowed

, and later the rule "VPC group with other SGs allowed" gets deleted.

If the user make any changes to the security group X, the rule "TCP (22) 521426283155/ VPC group with other SGs allowed" will be automatically removed during the edit process. The concern is that currently there exists no mechanism to warn user when this action is taken.

Feel free to check out the implementation in the "GUI-1266" branch to produce the case above.

[~kyolee] I see. Can we pop up a confirmation modal box for the condition when this will happen, when the security group detail page is displayed.

Let me know if that makes sense to you and if so, Ill add this info to the wireframe too.

[~jloza] Given the mechanics of how the security group view page is interacting with the security group rule panel, it would be much less intrusive if the warning modal would appear in the beginning when the security group detail page is loaded for the first time, warning the user about the fact that the current security group rules contain a rule or rules that allow traffic from a deleted security group or groups and giving a notice that any following update would automatically remove such rules.

Please let me know if this option would work for the page.

Thank you!

Kyo
hi [~kyolee], we can discuss this on the phone today in your 1:1...

Pull request has been created at:

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/968
punting back to have [~kyolee] investigate if security groups can be shared across accounts. This ticket may be partially or completely obsolete in light of that and GUI-901.

[~jloza][~kgill] Based on the conversation on 

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-6044

The fix was made to allow a security group rule to be deleted even some other security groups' rules depend on it. See the comment by [~spark] below:

"Currently we delete the ELB SG when ELB is deleted, but this leaves the rule in another SG and the rule can't be revoked because source SG is not found.

Two ways to solve the problem:
– do not allow deleting source SG when it's in the rule of another SG (that's the AWS behavior). However, this has the problem with ELB because ELB has no way of knowing whether its SG is in the rule of another ..."


As mentioned above, the fix for this issue was to allow the SG to be deleted while other SGs depend on it and allow the rules to be revoked later.

This means that GUI-901 needs to be implemented so that it handles the rules separately. With that implementation, we could prevent the rules from automatically removed if they are not valid. However, the warning modal on the client still needs to be in place to warn the user about the invalid rules.

Please let us know what you think on this issue.

Kyo
[~kyolee], I can't tell if we can tell if a rule can reference a security group in another account or not?

[~kyolee]: Thanks for digging further.  

I'm confused with the following two statements, which seem to contradict one another…

"Currently we delete the ELB SG when ELB is deleted,  but this leaves the rule in another SG and the rule can't be revoked because source SG is not found."

"As mentioned above, the fix for this issue was to allow the SG to be deleted while other SGs depend on it and allow the rules to be revoked later."

So could you clarify if we are allowing rules to be revoked if one of the rules has a deleted security group?

Q - I can't tell if we can tell if a rule can reference a security group in another account or not?

A- Yes.

Issue in EUCA-6044 - "Currently we delete the ELB SG when ELB is deleted, but this leaves the rule in another SG and the rule can't be revoked because source SG is not found."

Fix made in EUCA-6044 - "As mentioned above, the fix for this issue was to allow the SG to be deleted while other SGs depend on it and allow the rules to be revoked later."

Q - So could you clarify if we are allowing rules to be revoked if one of the rules has a deleted security group?

A - Yes

[~kyolee] Thanks for clarifying. If we restricted the scope of this ticket to just the warning message, how can you tell the difference between a rule that references a deleted security group and one that references a valid security group in another account?

The warning takes places on the client side where it compares the rules' allowed security groups with the list of the available security groups returned by boto's "get_all_security_groups()" call. If there exists mismatch, it assumes that such security groups are no longer accessible by the user, thus displays the warning modal.
but that only displays the security groups in the user's account, right?

get_all_security_groups(groupnames=None, group_ids=None, filters=None, dry_run=False)

Get all security groups associated with your account in a region.

OK, so if we warn based on that, we might be giving people false information, telling them a rule references an invalid security group that is actually valid, just in a different account. That makes me feel we should not be warning at all. Lying to users is not a way to make them happy. 

Let me know if I am misunderstanding what you are saying, please.
The boto's get_all_security_groups() call should return all the security groups accessible by the user's account, otherwise you wouldn't be able to include them in the rules in the first place.

In addition to the comment above, the mechanics of how the invalid rules are detected shouldn't be the center of the discussion for it can be adjusted. The main point for this fix is to provide a way for UI to warn the user about the invalid security rules proactively so that the user can take a proper action if it occurs. Otherwise, the user would be unknowingly relying on the stale rules that no longer have any effect.

The important thing is that we are not telling users untruths in the warning, which it sounds like we are not. [~kgill], I would think we could reduce the scope of this ticket to merely providing the warning dialog and not taking any action on the rules themselves, leaving that for GUI-901.

Agreed?

FYI, without GUI-901 implemented at the moment, when trying to update a security group with invalid rules would result in deleting of all rules.

The current fix in GUI-1266, at least, prevents such disastrous case by simply removing invalid rules during the "add_rules()" phase on the server.
[~jloza], [~kyolee]: I'm fine with including the scope of GUI-901 in this ticket (GUI-1266), since the two are so closely related and 901 purely involves refactoring.

Pull request, that contains GUI-1266 and GUI-901, is created for UX review:

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/993

In order to test this, create a security group with a rule that uses another security group as a source security group, then delete the source security group. At this point, the detail page will warn user about the invalid rule.

And, for the GUI-901 this re-factoring, now we no longer remove all the rules before re-adding them when the update of the security group rules request is received, thus in case of a failure in the middle of the update, we will not lose all the rules, preventing the worst case scenario.

There is no defined way to test this behavior since it all happens in the backend. Suggested testing methods for this fix is to perform multiple, complex operations by adding and removing of the security group rules to ensure that the rule updates are performed correctly, both on Eucalyptus and AWS.

[~kyolee] our dev cloud does not have VPC on it, and I can't review this against AWS because euca behavior is different. 

Please find me so we can screen share and you can show me this on whatever machine you've been developing against, or give me an IP to point at, please.

[~jloza] You can use my setup whose CLC is located at 10.111.1.173

ui-test-acct-00/admin/mypassword0
used your setup, clicked on "No VPC security group" which seems to reference a security group I don't see, and no warning displayed.
[~jloza] Please check again. Be sure to refresh the browser and disable the JS from being cached. See the attachment for what it will look like,
cleared cache, refreshed, nothing changed

Again, I was able to verify the fix on 2 different browsers. The issue must be coming from your local setup. Please try to take some time to resolve the case rather than just tossing the ticket back to me.

[~kyolee] Reassigning the ticket to you until you can work with me via screenshare or something to help resolve my issue. Otherwise this ticket will sit here forever. 

Please ping me in IRC when you have time to screenshare and help figure this out.
tried on FF, cache cleared and disabled, still no warning message when selecting No VPC security group which appears to reference a nonexistent security group
finally figured out WTF was going on. Updated message text, ready for code review.
Pull request 993 merged

Works as expected.  Created security group "one", created another security group "two", which contains an inbound rule that references group "one".  Edits made to "two" no longer wipe out all rules, instead displaying the "Warning: invalid rules…" dialog as expected.

Tested with the following…
Account: ui-test-acct-02/admin
CLC Host: 10.111.5.201
Console package: 4.1.0-0.0.4989.283.20141217git3404a55.el6 
Browser: Firefox 34
